content.description: Begin with your hands around the sloper and your feet against the opposing rock foot. There will be a crevasse by the start hold which you will be able to slide your hands into. Traverse the rock sideways via the generous crimps in the center of the rock. When you reach the ledge, you will be able to perform a mantle of sorts. The rest of the climb is pretty straightforward.
content.location: This climb will be straight in front of you facing north and work left.

content.description: Start as low as possible. You can exit either left or right at the top. Very likely this was climbed earlier than 2015, but the page exists now so thought I’d add it.
content.location: An obvious stack of boulders on the right side of the wash with a clean sandy landing.

content.description: This is a simple and straightforward rout. Begin with your hands around the ledge and your feet on the long foothold. Make your way up the sideways ledge and eventually mantle on to it.
content.location: In the section of boulders, this one is on the left when you are facing North.

content.description: Blue wash trail is a heavily trafficked trail in central AZ. The trail is free for all, and accessed via a small parking area off the road. Throughout the trail, there is a variety of boulders and climbing routes available to climb. Some of the rocks are flaky, so exercise caution. This particular boulder is not flaky at all. The rock is firm and there are two sections in which bouldering would be quite good. This is only mapping out the left side, but upon approach, you will be able to see a right side in which some overhang boulder routes could be established. The area becomes shaded about an hour prior to sunset.
